column1: Feudalism was a combination of legal and military customs in medieval Europe that flourished between the 9th and 15th centuries. Broadly defined
column2: it was a way of structuring society around relationships derived from the holding of land in exchange for service or labour.Although derived from the Latin word feodum or feudum (fief)
column4: the term feudalism and the system it describes were not conceived of as a formal political system by the people living in the Middle Ages. In its classic definition
column6: feudalism describes a set of reciprocal legal and military obligations among the warrior nobility
column7: revolving around the three key concepts of lords
column8: vassals and fiefs.A broader definition of feudalism
column10: includes not only the obligations of the warrior nobility but those of all three estates of the realm: the nobility
column12: and the peasantry bound by manorialism; this is sometimes referred to as a "feudal society".
